author: Gavin Finch
title: Hayes Posted Rate Moves on Facebook: ‘Tom Needs a Low 1m Libor’
text:
Former UBS Group AG trader Thomas Hayes was so obsessed with Libor that he dreamt about the benchmark and used Facebook to show which way he wanted the rate to go.
Hayes posted status updates such as “Tom needs a low 1m Libor” four or five times on the social networking site, the derivatives trader told the Serious Fraud Office in a 2013 interview played to a London jury today by U.K. prosecutors.
The 35-year-old Hayes has pleaded not guilty to eight counts of conspiracy to manipulate the London interbank offered rate, the benchmark used to value more than $350 trillion of loans and securities. Each count carries as much as 10 years in prison.
Hayes told the SFO that the Facebook posts weren’t an attempt to manipulate the rate as he wasn’t friends with anyone in the market, but were an expression of what he wanted to see happen.
“Either I’m the stupidest fraudster ever because I wrote everything down or there was an element of me that actually just genuinely didn’t think anything about it,” Hayes said in the SFO interview. “I might be a lot of things, but I’m not stupid.”
Prosecutors say Hayes bullied and cajoled fellow traders and brokers to move benchmark rates to make his positions more profitable. Hayes’s lawyers say the practice was widespread.
“I used to dream about libors,” Hayes told the SFO. “They were my bread and butter, you know. That was the thing. They were the instrument that underlined everything that I traded.”
